newsitem.title: SLOVAKIA: Slovak 1996 trade gap seen at SKK 40-55 bln-report.
newsitem.headline: Slovak 1996 trade gap seen at SKK 40-55 bln-report.

text.p: Slovakia's foreign trade deficit for 1996 is expected to total between 40 to 55 billion crowns, according to the latest forecast of the National Bank of Slovakia (NBS), the independent daily SME said on Monday.
The daily quoted NBS governor Vladimir Masar, but NBS officials were not available for comment on the report.
Slovakia's trade deficit widened to 31.89 billion crowns in the first seven months of this year, from a deficit of 26.97 billion crowns in the January-June period.

The original NBS forecast for the 1996 foreign trade balance, made at the beginning of the year, was for a deficit of around 11 billion crowns. In 1995 Slovakia posted a foreign trade surplus of 1.8 billion crowns.

Government officials have said the turnabout was no cause for concern, as imports, totalling 182.13 billion crowns in January-July period, included oil, technology and investment goods needed to restructure the country's economy. -- Peter Laca, Bratislava Newsroom, 42-7-210-3687
